title: How to Deep Clean Your Keyboard (And Why You Should Do It Now)
description: Keyboards are dirtier than toilet seats. Here is a step-by-step guide to safely cleaning your mechanical or laptop keyboard.
author: Free Online Typing Team
content:
The Shocking Truth About Keyboard Cleanliness

Your keyboard is likely one of the dirtiest objects you touch daily. Multiple studies have found that keyboards harbor more bacteria than toilet seats—in some cases, up to 20,000 times more bacteria per square inch. Between the keys lurks a disgusting mixture of dead skin cells, food particles, hair, dust, pet dander, and countless microorganisms including potentially harmful bacteria like E. coli and Staphylococcus.

Beyond the hygiene concerns, dirty keyboards perform poorly. Accumulated debris can cause keys to stick, reduce switch lifespan, interfere with mechanical switch operation, and even cause electrical problems in extreme cases. Regular keyboard cleaning isn't just about aesthetics—it's about health, hygiene, and maintaining optimal typing performance.

This comprehensive guide covers everything you need to know about deep cleaning your keyboard, from quick daily maintenance to thorough deep cleaning procedures for both mechanical and membrane keyboards.

Why Regular Keyboard Cleaning Matters

Health and Hygiene

Keyboards are breeding grounds for germs, especially if you eat at your desk or share your workspace with others. During cold and flu season, contaminated keyboards can harbor viruses for days, potentially spreading illness to anyone who uses them. Regular cleaning with disinfectant reduces bacterial load and helps prevent illness transmission.

Performance and Longevity

Dirt, dust, and debris interfere with mechanical switch operation, causing mushiness, inconsistent actuation, or complete key failure. Spills that aren't properly cleaned can corrode electrical contacts and permanently damage keyboard electronics. Regular cleaning extends keyboard lifespan and maintains optimal typing feel.

Professional Appearance

A clean keyboard projects professionalism and attention to detail. Whether you're working from home on video calls or in an office environment, a pristine keyboard makes a better impression than one caked with grime and crumbs.

Tools and Materials Needed

Essential Cleaning Supplies

  • Compressed air or electric duster: For blowing out debris from between keys
  • Isopropyl alcohol (90% or higher): For disinfecting and dissolving oils without damaging electronics
  • Microfiber cloths: Lint-free cloths that won't scratch surfaces or leave residue
  • Cotton swabs (Q-tips): For detailed cleaning around keys and tight spaces
  • Keycap puller: Essential for mechanical keyboards (wire pullers are gentler than plastic ones)
  • Small brush: Soft-bristled brush or old toothbrush for scrubbing
  • Bowl for soaking keycaps: Large enough to submerge all keycaps
  • Mild dish soap: For washing keycaps
  • Towels for drying: Clean towels to lay out keycaps for air drying

Optional Advanced Tools

  • Keyboard cleaning gel/putty: Sticky putty that picks up debris from between keys
  • UV sanitizer: For killing bacteria without liquids
  • Switch lubricant: For re-lubing switches during deep cleaning (mechanical keyboards only)
  • Desoldering equipment: For complete disassembly of soldered keyboards (advanced users)

Quick Daily Maintenance (5 Minutes)

Daily light cleaning prevents massive buildup and makes deep cleaning easier. This routine takes just a few minutes:

  1. Turn off and unplug your keyboard or disconnect wireless connection
  2. Turn keyboard upside down and gently shake to dislodge loose debris
  3. Use compressed air to blow out dust from between keys, working in short bursts at an angle
  4. Wipe down keycaps with a lightly dampened microfiber cloth (water or diluted isopropyl alcohol)
  5. Clean around the bezel and any crevices where dust accumulates

Perform this routine daily if you eat at your desk, or 2-3 times weekly for typical use.

Deep Cleaning Mechanical Keyboards (45-90 Minutes)

Step 1: Preparation and Documentation

Before beginning, take a photo of your keyboard layout. This reference is invaluable when reassembling, especially for non-standard layouts or if you're unfamiliar with your keyboard's layout. Gather all cleaning supplies and set up a clean workspace with adequate lighting.

Step 2: Unplug and Initial Cleaning

Disconnect your keyboard completely. Turn it upside down and gently shake to dislodge loose debris. Use compressed air to blow out surface dust, holding the can upright and using short bursts to avoid liquid propellant discharge.

Step 3: Remove Keycaps

Using a keycap puller, gently remove all keycaps by pulling straight up with even pressure. Work systematically across the keyboard to avoid confusion during reassembly. Place removed keycaps in a large bowl or container.

Special considerations:

  • Remove larger keys (spacebar, shift, enter) carefully to avoid damaging stabilizer wires
  • Note the orientation of stabilizer bars before removal
  • Keep stabilizers attached to the keyboard unless they require cleaning or maintenance

Step 4: Clean the Keyboard Base

With keycaps removed, the keyboard base is exposed. This is the dirtiest part you've never seen—prepare to be disgusted!

  • Compressed air: Thoroughly blow out all debris from between switches and around the PCB
  • Soft brush: Gently brush away stubborn debris, being careful around exposed switches
  • Isopropyl alcohol and cotton swabs: Clean around each switch housing, removing oils and grime
  • Microfiber cloth with alcohol: Wipe down the plate, case edges, and any exposed surfaces

For extremely dirty keyboards, consider using a vacuum with a soft brush attachment (on low power) to remove debris before using compressed air.

Step 5: Wash Keycaps

While the keyboard base dries, clean your keycaps thoroughly:

  1. Fill a large bowl or sink with warm (not hot) water and a few drops of mild dish soap
  2. Submerge all keycaps and let them soak for 30-45 minutes to loosen grime
  3. Agitate and scrub: Swish keycaps around, then use a soft brush to scrub each keycap individually, paying attention to the sides and undersides where oils accumulate
  4. Rinse thoroughly with clean water to remove all soap residue
  5. Dry completely: Lay keycaps on a clean towel and allow to air dry for several hours or overnight. Do NOT reassemble with damp keycaps—moisture can damage switches and PCB

Important: Some specialty keycaps (double-shot ABS with colored legends, vintage keycaps, or those with painted legends) may require gentler cleaning. Test a single cap first if unsure.

Step 6: Clean or Replace Stabilizers

If your stabilizers rattle or feel scratchy, this is the perfect time to service them:

  • Remove stabilizers from the keyboard (if removable)
  • Clean stabilizer housing and wires with isopropyl alcohol
  • Apply dielectric grease to wire ends and inside housing for smooth, quiet operation
  • Reassemble stabilizers correctly (check orientation!)

Step 7: Reassemble

Once everything is completely dry (wait at least 4-6 hours for keycaps, overnight to be safe):

  1. Reference your layout photo
  2. Install larger stabilized keys first (spacebar, shifts, enter, backspace)
  3. Install remaining keycaps, working systematically across the keyboard
  4. Press each key to ensure proper seating and function
  5. Reconnect keyboard and test all keys

Deep Cleaning Membrane and Laptop Keyboards

Membrane keyboards can't be disassembled as easily as mechanical keyboards, requiring different cleaning approaches.

Surface Cleaning

  1. Unplug or power off completely
  2. Turn upside down and shake gently
  3. Use compressed air between keys
  4. Dampen microfiber cloth with 70% isopropyl alcohol
  5. Wipe each keycap thoroughly
  6. Use cotton swabs dipped in alcohol for crevices between keys
  7. Allow to dry completely before use (15-30 minutes)

Deep Cleaning (Advanced)

Some membrane keyboards allow keycap removal, though it's more delicate than mechanical keyboards:

  • Carefully pry off keycaps with a flat tool (keycap puller or small flathead screwdriver)
  • Work slowly—membrane dome sheets are fragile
  • Clean exposed membrane with cotton swabs and alcohol
  • Wash keycaps as described for mechanical keyboards
  • Ensure everything is bone dry before reassembly

Warning: Many laptop keyboards cannot be cleaned deeply without complete disassembly. For laptops, stick to surface cleaning unless you're comfortable with laptop disassembly.

Dealing with Spills

Immediate Response (Critical First Minutes)

  1. Disconnect power immediately—every second counts
  2. Turn keyboard upside down to drain liquid away from electronics
  3. Shake gently to expel as much liquid as possible
  4. Do not try to test the keyboard—powering on wet electronics can cause permanent damage

Water Spills

Water is relatively harmless if cleaned quickly:

  1. Disassemble as much as possible (remove keycaps, separate case from PCB if feasible)
  2. Rinse PCB with distilled water to remove any contaminants
  3. Pat dry with lint-free cloth
  4. Allow to air dry completely for 48-72 hours
  5. Use fans or place in warm (not hot) area to accelerate drying

Sugary or Sticky Drinks

Soda, juice, or sweetened beverages require more aggressive cleaning:

  1. Follow immediate response steps
  2. Completely disassemble keyboard
  3. Rinse affected components with distilled water repeatedly
  4. Clean sticky residue with isopropyl alcohol on cotton swabs
  5. Dry thoroughly for 48-72 hours minimum

Coffee or Milk

Proteins and fats in coffee with cream or milk can corrode electronics:

  • Complete disassembly is essential
  • Clean all components thoroughly with isopropyl alcohol
  • May require ultrasonic cleaning for PCB (professional service)
  • Even with proper cleaning, long-term damage is possible

Preventive Measures

Daily Habits

  • Don't eat over your keyboard—crumbs are inevitable
  • Keep drinks away from your workspace or use spill-proof containers
  • Wash hands before extended typing sessions
  • Use keyboard cover when not in use (dust protection)

Workspace Environment

  • Keep workspace clean and dust-free
  • Use air purifier to reduce airborne particles
  • Regularly clean desk surface
  • Control humidity to prevent sticky keys

Cleaning Schedule Recommendations

  • Daily: Quick wipe-down of keycap surfaces
  • Weekly: Compressed air cleaning between keys
  • Monthly: Thorough surface cleaning with alcohol
  • Quarterly: Deep cleaning with keycap removal (mechanical keyboards)
  • Annually: Complete disassembly and detailed cleaning including lubrication

Conclusion: Clean Keyboard, Happy Typing

Regular keyboard cleaning is a simple investment that pays dividends in health, performance, and equipment longevity. While deep cleaning requires time and effort, the results are worth it: a keyboard that looks new, types smoothly, and won't make you sick. Make keyboard cleaning part of your regular maintenance routine, and your keyboard will serve you well for years to come.

Now that you know the shocking truth about keyboard cleanliness and have a comprehensive cleaning guide, there's no excuse for a dirty keyboard. Set aside time this weekend for a deep clean—your keyboard (and immune system) will thank you!
